access.description: The registered URL returns HTTP 200 directly with static HTML content. No redirects, no anti-bot protection, no JavaScript rendering required. The page is a clean landing page that links to two configuration detail pages and three PDF data dictionaries. All public documentation is accessible without authentication. A link to 'Regulatory EHI Export Functionality Guides' at customer.meditech.com requires SAML/Keycloak login — these appear to be operational guides rather than data specifications.

product_context.description: MEDITECH is one of the largest EHR vendors in the US, particularly dominant in community hospitals and mid-size health systems. The product is a comprehensive Healthcare Information System (HCIS) spanning clinical, financial, and administrative domains. MEDITECH Expanse (current flagship) includes full EHR, Revenue Cycle/billing, Patient Connect portal with messaging, ambulatory/practice management with scheduling, pharmacy, ED, oncology, pathology, radiology, population health, surgical services, home care, mental health, and post-acute care. The certified modules collectively represent the entire HCIS — Core HCIS, ED Management, Ambulatory, Oncology, MyHealth Portal, and public health interfaces. The product spans multiple platform generations: Expanse 2.2/2.1 (current), 6.15/6.08 (prior), Client/Server 5.67, and MAGIC 5.67 (legacy). Each generation has a different EHI export configuration, with Expanse being the most widely deployed currently.
product_context.certified_module_name: MEDITECH Expanse 2.2 Core HCIS (and many others across platform generations)

export_approach.description: MEDITECH uses a hybrid/mixed export approach that combines multiple formats within a single ZIP file. The export contains: (1) Electronic Chart documents — scanned/archived clinical documents as PDF/image files organized in category/subcategory folders; (2) US Core FHIR R4 resources — a JSON bundle via Patient $everything conforming to US Core STU 3.1.1; (3) C-CDA documents — structured clinical summaries; (4) Supplemental reports — financial, authorization, immunization, population health, utilization review data as text/PDF files; (5) For older platforms (Config 2: C/S, MAGIC, MPM 6.08), CSV files extracted from the Data Repository with structured table/column data. The approach varies significantly by platform generation. Notably, the newer Expanse platforms rely more heavily on the Electronic Chart (scanned documents) + FHIR + reports model, while older platforms additionally provide CSV data extracts from the Data Repository. The FHIR component covers standard US Core resources but would not include billing detail, messages (beyond clinical notes), or audit data. Financial data is exported as a text report (FinancialEHI.txt) rather than structured tabular data. Authorization data is exported as PDF. A Table of Contents in NDJSON (FHIR DocumentReference resources) provides machine-readable metadata for all files in the ZIP.

documentation_quality.description: The documentation is well-organized at the structural level — it clearly describes the folder hierarchy, file naming conventions, and what each section contains. However, the depth of documentation varies dramatically by platform. For older platforms (C/S, MAGIC, MPM 6.08), three PDF data dictionaries provide field-level detail mapping ~94-318 database tables with ~466-1,211 columns each, showing Field name, Table name, and Column name. These are genuine data repository schema documentation. For the newer Expanse platform (the most widely deployed), no equivalent field-level documentation exists — the documentation only describes sections at the folder/file level (e.g., 'FinancialEHI.txt — Contains a Patient Accounting report that includes financial transactions'). The FHIR component references US Core STU 3.1.1 at fhir.meditech.com but does not document MEDITECH-specific extensions or resource coverage. The PDFs are dated October 2023. No sample data, no value sets, no relationship documentation. The structural documentation is clear enough to understand what you'll get, but for Expanse users, you won't know the specific fields until you receive the actual export.

ehi_coverage.overall_assessment: MEDITECH's EHI export is a genuinely comprehensive attempt to cover all EHI categories, particularly impressive for the older platforms (C/S, MAGIC) where the CSV data extract from the Data Repository includes hundreds of tables spanning clinical, administrative, financial, and scheduling data at the field level. The export clearly includes financial transactions (PbrAccountTransactions, PbrAccountClaims), insurance data (AdmInsurances, AdmInsuredInfo with copay/deductible/policy/group), scheduling (SchAppointments plus extensive surgical case management), provider-patient messages, clinical documentation, and some audit trails. For the newer Expanse platform, the export takes a more document-centric approach — Electronic Chart files + FHIR + C-CDA + supplemental reports — which likely covers the same data categories but through rendered reports rather than structured database extracts. The financial data being exported as a text report (FinancialEHI.txt) rather than structured CSV on newer platforms is a step backward in machine-readability. The Authorization & Referral Management data is exported as PDF, which is also less machine-readable than structured data. Portal messages appear covered via 'Patient Notices' (6.08) and 'Provider Messages' (C/S, MAGIC) sections, and the CSV tables include AprEncMessages/AprEncMessagesLines. Audit data is limited — there's a PhaRxAuditDetailText table for medication audit trails in C/S, but no comprehensive access audit log. Overall, this is one of the more thorough EHI exports among major vendors, but the quality and machine-readability varies significantly by platform generation.

clinical.evidence: Extensive clinical coverage across all platforms. Config 1: Electronic Chart documents (organized by account/category/subcategory), C-CDA documents, FHIR US Core resources (Patient $everything), Ambulatory Results PDFs, Immunization History, Population Health, Implantable Devices. Config 2 CSV tables include: OeOrders (order entry with 6 detail tables), PhaRx (pharmacy with ~30+ tables covering medications, administrations, ADRs, interventions), LabSpecimens/LabSpecimenTests, MicSpecimens (microbiology), PthSpecimens (pathology), ItsOrder (imaging/radiology), NurPatientPoc (nursing plans of care), HubPatientProblems (problem lists), EpsFamilyHistory (family history), EdmPatientNotes (ED notes), BbkSpecimens (blood bank). Clinical documentation is comprehensive.

secure_messages.evidence: Config 1 includes 'Provider Messages' section for C/S and MAGIC platforms (Provider Messages.txt containing 'patient and physician interactive message') and 'Patient Notices' for 6.08 (Patient Notices.pdf). Config 2 explicitly lists 'Provider and Patient Messages' section with 'Provider to Provider and Provider to Patient messaging' in both PDF and TXT formats with embedded images. CSV tables include AprEncMessages and AprEncMessagesLines (ambulatory encounter messages) and PbrMpiVisVisitsMessagesText (visit messages in MAGIC). The MyHealth Portal is a certified module, and messaging appears covered, though the documentation for Expanse doesn't explicitly detail portal message export at field level.

billing_financial.evidence: Config 1 includes 'Financial Reports' section with FinancialEHI.txt ('Patient Accounting report that includes financial transactions'), ResidentTrustEHI.txt (financial transactions for resident trust), and CostEstimation.txt (Expanse only). Config 2 also includes Financial Reports with FinancialEHI.txt. The CSV data dictionaries contain extensive billing tables: PbrAccountTransactions (transaction type, amounts), PbrAccountClaims (claim numbers), PbrAccountClaimsDetail (transaction sequences, amounts, patient responsible amounts), PbrAccountStatements/PbrAccountStatementDetail, PbrAccountTxnFinanceCharges, PbrAccountTxnPymntDistribution, PbrAcctTxnDxs (transaction diagnoses). These cover charges, claims, payments, and payment distribution. However, on Expanse the financial data is a text report rather than structured CSV.

insurance_coverage.evidence: CSV tables include: AdmInsurances (InsuranceID, Address, OtherName), AdmInsuredInfo/AdmInsuredData (PolicyNumber, GroupNumber, GroupName, EffectiveDate, ExpirationDate, CoverageNumber, InsuranceBenefitPlan, Copay, Deductible, ElectronicCheck, TreatmentAuthorizationNumber), MriPatientInsurances (with multiple insurance-related fields). Config 1 includes 'Authorization & Referral Management Reports' with ARMEHI-ArmAuthData.pdf (all authorizations and referrals) and ARMEHI-InsEligCopayDeductData.pdf (insurance eligibility and deduction data). CSV tables also include ArmAuths, ArmAuthServices, ArmAuthServiceScheduledUnits, ArmAuthServicePerformedUnits. RxmRxPriorAuthorization table covers medication prior authorizations.

appointments_scheduling.evidence: CSV tables include SchAppointments (AppointmentTypeID and related fields) and an extensive set of surgical scheduling tables (~60+ tables): SchOrPatCase* (actual operations, complications, devices, dressings, equipment, implants, invasive procedures, IVs, medications, CPTs, vital signs across all surgical phases — pre-op, intra-op, PACU, holding, phase 1-4), SchPatNotes* (anesthesia, holding, OR, PACU, pre-op notes). This is primarily OR scheduling rather than general appointment scheduling. ArmAuthServiceScheduledUnits also references appointments in the context of authorizations.

documents_images.evidence: Config 1: Electronic Chart section contains documents as images (png, jpg, tif, bmp) and PDFs organized in account/category/subcategory folders, including account-level, record-level, and global documents. Historical Ambulatory Data folder with migrated documents. Config 2: Clinical Reports/Documents (physician documentation, radiology reports, pathology reports with images, nursing image documentation), External Documents/Images (AmbScans folder with scanned/imported external documents in PDF, DOCX, DOC, TXT, HTML, RTF, ODT, TIF, PNG, JPG, BMP, GIF formats), Point of Contact Scanned Documents. The export supports a wide range of image and document formats.

audit_trails.evidence: Very limited audit trail coverage. The CSV tables include PhaRxAuditDetailText (medication audit trail) and PbrMpiVisHlthMntItemsAudit (health maintenance item audit), but these are narrow medication/clinical audit trails, not comprehensive access logs showing who viewed or modified patient records. There is no general audit trail table (e.g., who accessed the record, when, what they viewed/changed). The EdmPatientDocumentSigHistory table (MAGIC) suggests some document signature history. Given MEDITECH is a full HCIS that certainly maintains comprehensive audit logs internally, the absence of a general access audit trail from the export is a notable gap.

issues: No field-level documentation for MEDITECH Expanse (the most widely deployed current platform) — only folder/file structure descriptions are provided, while the detailed CSV table/column PDFs cover only older platforms (C/S, MAGIC, MPM 6.08).
Financial data on newer platforms (Expanse, 6.1x) is exported as a text report (FinancialEHI.txt) rather than structured CSV/JSON, reducing machine-readability for the most important billing data.
Authorization and referral data is exported as PDF reports (ARMEHI-ArmAuthData.pdf, ARMEHI-InsEligCopayDeductData.pdf), not as structured machine-readable data.
No comprehensive access audit trail is included in the export despite MEDITECH certainly maintaining detailed audit logs internally.
The 'Regulatory EHI Export Functionality Guides' are behind a customer login wall at customer.meditech.com, which may contain additional data specifications not available publicly.
Immunization history is exported as PDF (Patient Immunization History.pdf) rather than structured data on Config 1 platforms, though FHIR Immunization resources would provide structured coverage.

Export content varies significantly across platform generations, creating an inconsistent experience — customers on older platforms (C/S, MAGIC) actually get more granular structured data via CSV than customers on the newer Expanse platform.
Documentation was last updated October 2023, potentially missing export enhancements since then.

Some sections export data as rendered PDF reports rather than structured data (Ambulatory Results, Authorization reports, Immunization History, Utilization Review, Population Health), limiting downstream machine processing.

downloaded_files.description: Main EHI Export landing page with two-configuration overview table and links to detail pages
Configuration 1 detail page covering Expanse, 6.x, C/S Acute, MAGIC Acute — section-level export structure documentation
Configuration 2 detail page covering MPM 6.08, C/S, MAGIC with DR/MRI — includes links to CSV data dictionary PDFs
CSV table/column data dictionary for MPM 6.08 Ambulatory platform — 19 pages, ~94 tables, ~466 field mappings, last updated October 2023

CSV table/column data dictionary for Client/Server Acute & Ambulatory platform — 20 pages, ~318 tables, ~1,211 field mappings, last updated October 2023. Covers admissions, insurance, orders, pharmacy, lab, pathology, radiology, ED, scheduling/OR, billing (PbrAccount*), nursing, problems, and more.

CSV table/column data dictionary for MAGIC Acute & Ambulatory platform — 20 pages, ~308 tables, ~1,081 field mappings, last updated October 2023. Similar coverage to C/S with MAGIC-specific table naming.

summary: MEDITECH provides a well-documented hybrid EHI export that combines Electronic Chart documents, FHIR US Core resources, C-CDA clinical summaries, CSV data extracts (older platforms), and supplemental text/PDF reports into a single ZIP file. The export covers all 7 EHI categories including billing transactions, insurance details, scheduling, provider-patient messages, and clinical documentation — making it one of the more complete EHI exports among major vendors. However, there is a significant documentation asymmetry: older platforms (C/S, MAGIC) have detailed field-level CSV data dictionaries covering 300+ tables, while the current Expanse platform lacks equivalent field-level documentation and exports some data (financial, authorization) as rendered text/PDF reports rather than structured data. The absence of comprehensive access audit trails is the most notable data gap.
notes: MEDITECH's approach of maintaining two export configurations creates complexity but reflects the reality of supporting multiple platform generations simultaneously. The older platforms paradoxically provide a more complete structured data export (CSV from the Data Repository) than the newer Expanse platform, which relies more on document-based export. The FHIR component (US Core STU 3.1.1 via Patient $everything) provides standard structured clinical data but by definition cannot cover billing, messaging, or audit data. The Table of Contents.ndjson using FHIR DocumentReference resources is a thoughtful touch for machine navigation of the export package. The export documentation site is clean, well-organized, and technically accessible — a model for how to publish EHI export documentation, even if the Expanse field-level detail is lacking.
